When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return to the original), it often finds itself in a different environment from that in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it had before.
The original population has not changed at all, it still needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble the other population less and less.
Finally, after millions or even billions of years, the two populations will appear so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

The technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense that the fate of humanity is dictated by a underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: technological development itself occurs according to a process that exceeds cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, one could say that the car necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.

The use of ships for the transport of goods is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across oceans.

The work of the marines traditionally has been to ensure that your country retains the ability to move your people and your goods, while interfering with the ability of your enemy to move his people and his goods.

One of the most recent notable examples of this situation was the North Atlantic campaign during World War II. The Americans tried to make it across the Atlantic Ocean to soldiers and equipment to help the British.
At the same time the German Navy, using mainly U-Boats, was trying to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have been able to conquer Britain as it did for the rest of Europe.
It seems that goats were domesticated for the first time about 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains in Iran.
The ancient cultures and tribes began to keep them close to them to have easy access to milk, hair, meat and skins.

Domestic goats were usually kept in herds that wandered on the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were usually children or adolescents, similar to the more well-known term of shepherds. These pastoral methods have always been in use today.
Wagonways were built in England as early as the 16th century.
Although the tracks were simply wooden planks laid parallel to each other, they allowed horses to reach higher speeds and to pull heavier loads than on the slightly more uneven roads of the day.
The crossbars were introduced fairly early to keep the tracks in place. However, it soon became apparent that tracks would be more effective if they were fitted with a strip of iron on top.
This has become a common practice, but iron has caused more wear on wooden wheels of wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.
The first means of locomotion was walking: humans began to walk upright about two million years ago with the arrival of Homo Erectus ("upright man").
Their predecessors, the australopithecines, did not walk upright as usual.
Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus could have walked on two legs seven million years ago.

It is clear that the world has changed a lot thanks to the scientific and technological advances made by humans, and that the problems have become more important due to the overpopulation and extravagant lifestyle of humanity.

After its adoption by Congress on July 4, a manuscript signed by the President of Congress John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few blocks away, to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, today known as "Dunlap Broadside".
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in the hall of Independence on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on June 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap leaves still known to exist are the oldest copies of the document. The original handwritten copy has not survived.
Many palaeontologists now think that a group of dinosaurs survived and is still alive. They are called birds.
Very few people consider them dinosaurs because they have wings and can fly.
But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like dinosaurs.
They have scales on their legs and claws, they lay eggs and walk on their hind legs like T-Rexes.
Practically all computers used today are based on the manipulation of information that is coded in binary numbers.
A binary number can only have one of two values: 0 or 1. These numbers are called binary numbers, or bits for the jargon of computer science.
An internal poisoning may not be immediately visible. Symptoms, such as vomiting, are sufficiently general to make an immediate diagnosis impossible.
The best indicator of internal poisoning is probably the presence of an open container of drugs or household chemicals.
Check the label for specific first aid instructions for this poison.
The term "insect" is used by entomologists in a formal sense for this group of insects.
This term derives from an old familiarity with bed bugs, which are very well adapted to parasitize humans.
Reductions, just like bed bugs, are nidicolous, which means they are adapted to live in the nest or the habitat of their host.
In the United States, there are about 400,000 known cases of multiple sclerosis (MS), which makes it the most common neurological disease in young and middle-aged adults.
Multiple sclerosis is a disease that affects the central nervous system, which consists of the brain, spinal cord and optic nerve.
Research has shown that women are twice as likely to have MS as men.

Many rhythms observed in physiology and behavior depend often in large part on the presence of endogenous cycles and their production by biological clocks.
Periodic rhythms, which are not simply responses to external periodic stimuli, have been documented for most living organisms, including bacteria, fungi, plants and animals.
Biological clocks are self-sustaining oscillators that will continue to operate for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.
The Hershey and Chase experiment was one of the main indications that DNA was a genetic material.
Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium.
They conducted two experiments to label either the phage DNA with radioactive phosphorus, or the phage protein with radioactive sulfur.
Mutations can have many different effects depending on the type of mutation, the importance of the part of the genetic material affected and if the affected cells are germ cells.
Only germ cell mutations can be passed on to children, while other mutations can lead to cell death or cancer.
Ecotourism interests people who wish to visit natural areas in order to enjoy the scenery, including fauna and flora.
Hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, visiting parks and studying the ecosystem are examples of activities on site.
One can, for example, go to see, photograph and discover orang-utans in Borneo.
Every morning, people leave the small towns of the countryside in their cars to go to work and cross other people who are going to work in the countryside they just left.
In this dynamic transportation shuttle, everyone is somehow connected to a transportation system based on private cars and support.
Science now shows that this carbon-based economy has displaced the biosphere from its stable state that has supported human evolution for two million years.
Everyone is part of society and uses transport systems. Almost everyone complains about transport systems.
In developed countries, it is rare to hear so many complaints about water quality or the collapse of bridges.
Why do transportation systems generate such complaints, why do they break down daily? Are transportation engineers simply incompetent? Or is there something more fundamental going on?
Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and private vehicles between two points, and the interactions they exert between themselves.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because drivers' behavior cannot be predicted with a hundred percent certainty.
Unfortunately, drivers tend to act in a fairly consistent range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a fairly consistent range and can be approximated mathematically.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) flow, (2) density and (3) speed.
These relationships help to plan, design, and operate road facilities.
Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape more easily from their enemies and to find more efficiently food and companions.
Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their bodies.
It gives them more places to hide from predators.
Today, the only insects that cannot fold their wings are dragonflies and ephemera.
About a thousand years ago, a man called Aristarque claimed that the solar system moved around the Sun.
Some thought he was right, but many believed the opposite: that the solar system moved around the Earth, including the Sun (and even the other stars).
It seems reasonable, because the Earth doesn't seem to move, doesn't it?
The Amazon River is the second longest and largest river on Earth. It carries more than eight times the volume of water of the second largest river.
The Amazon is also the largest river in the world, sometimes reaching 10 km in width.
Not less than 20 percent of the water that pours from rivers into the oceans comes from the Amazon.
The main arm of the Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 mi) long. It collects water from thousands of small rivers.

The ancient Egyptians of the New Kingdom were amazed by the monuments of their predecessors, who had then been around for more than a thousand years.
The Vatican has about 800 residents. It is the smallest independent country in the world, and the least populated.
Vatican City drafts its legislation and official communications in Italian.
Italian is also the language of everyday life used by most people working in the state, while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies.

The thickness of the crust is about 70 km on the visible side and 100 km on the hidden side.
It is thinner at the seas and thicker under continents.
There may be more maria on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for lava to rise to the surface.
Theories of content focus on what makes people feel good or attractive.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that have been internalized as they mature towards adulthood.
These theories examine what drives some people to want what they do and what, in their environment, drives them to do or not do certain things.
Two popular content theories are Maslow's hierarchy of needs theory and Herzberg's two-factor theory.
In general, two behaviors can emerge when a manager becomes the boss of former colleagues. On one end of the spectrum is trying to remain "the good friend" (or the good friend).
This type of manager has a hard time making unpopular decisions, taking disciplinary actions, conducting evaluations, assigning responsibilities, and holding others accountable.
At the other end of the spectrum, one turns into an unrecognizable individual who feels he or she must change everything that the group has created so far and do things his or her own way.
After all, the captain is ultimately responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to disagreements between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often function as the point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet in different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of a virtual team.
The "invisible team" is the management team to which each member is accountable. It sets standards for each of them.

Neuro-biological data provide evidence for a theoretical approach to the study of cognition. They therefore reduce the field of research and make it much more precise.
The correlation between brain pathology and behaviour supports scientists in their research.
It has long been known that different types of damage, lesions, tumors and brain trauma affect behavior and cause changes in certain mental functions.
The growth of new technologies allows us to see and study brain structures and processes that have never been seen before.
It gives us a lot of information and materials to build simulation models that help us understand the processes in our minds.

Although artificial intelligence is often strongly associated with science fiction, it represents a very important part of computer science that studies the behavior, learning and intelligent adaptation of a machine.
The research in artificial intelligence has as its object the automation by machines of tasks requiring intelligent approaches.
Among the examples are control, planning and programming, the ability to respond to diagnostics and questions of customers, as well as recognition of writing, voice and face.
These practices have led to distinct disciplines, focused on the contribution of solutions to everyday problems.
The AI system is now often used in the fields of economics, medicine, engineering and the military, as it has been implemented in several home computer and video game software.
Excursions are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take his or her students to places where a bus trip is not possible.

The solution is provided by technology in the form of virtual educational outings. Students can look at ancient objects in a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful work of art while sitting with their class.
Participating practically in an excursion is also an excellent way to think about a trip and to share experiences with future generations.

For example, students at Bennet College in North Carolina design a website each year about their visit to the state capital. Each year, the website is updated, but the old versions are kept online as an album.
Blogs can also help students improve their writing skills. Even though students often try out blogging with a poor grammar and spelling, having a public audience usually improves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the blogger begins to work on improving his writing to avoid criticism.
Also, blogging "obliges students to better understand the world around them". The need to attract public interest encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

"When used wisely, blogs can help students strengthen their analytical and critical thinking abilities: by actively reacting to online content, they can confront their opinions with those of others and expose their own views on specific topics."
Ottawa is the charming bilingual capital of Canada and has a large number of art galleries and museums that highlight the past and present of Canada.
You will find the Niagara Falls further south and the Muskoka region and its surrounding area which have a natural beauty unspoiled.
These measures, and many others, make Ontario what foreigners consider to be the quintessence of Canada.
Large areas further north are fairly sparsely populated and some are almost uninhabited in their natural state.

Madagascar is far the largest country, and even a continent on its own, in terms of wildlife.
Most of the small islands are independent nations, or associated with France, and are known for being luxury resorts.
The Arabs also brought the practice of Islam to the lands and this religion spread widely to Comoros and Mayotte.
European influence and colonialism began in the fifteenth century, when Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama discovered the Cape route that links Europe to India.
To the north, the region is bounded by the Sahel, and to the south and west by the Atlantic Ocean.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC, and was used by Phoenicians, Romans and the Almohads as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it, rebuilt it and christened it Casa Branca. They abandoned it in 1755 after a earthquake.
The sultan of Morocco rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tajines, pottery, leather goods, narguilés and all kinds of souvenirs, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist city located in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano which buried most of the city, in particular the downtown.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma must be researched to understand the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the Nyiragongo volcano as well as for the tracking of mountain gorillas among the least expensive gorilla tracking in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motorbike taxi) to get around Goma. The normal price (local) is about 500 francs Congolese for a short ride.
Combined with its relative remoteness, "Tombouctou" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.
Today, Tombouctou is a poor city, despite its reputation as a tourist attraction, and it has an airport.
In 1990, it was added to the list of endangered sites, due to the threat of sand dunes.
It was one of the main stages of the PBS documentary "Wonders of the African World" by Henry Louis Gates.
The city contrasts strongly with the rest of the country, as it has a more Arabic style than African.
The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in northeastern South Africa and runs along the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River border to the south.
The total surface of the park is 19,500 km², which is divided into 14 ecozones, each of which harbors a specific fauna.
It is one of the most famous amusement parks in South Africa and considered to be the crown jewel of SANParks.
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entry and conservation fees for the park.
It can be advantageous to get a Wild Card that gives access to some South African parks, as well as all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and is the main attraction for many tourists.
The row of skyscrapers that defines the horizon of Hong Kong has been compared to a scintillating bar graph that reveals itself by reflection in the waters of Victoria Harbour.
To admire the most breathtaking views of Hong Kong, leave the island and join the Kowloon front on the opposite side.
The majority of the urban development on Hong Kong Island is concentrated on the landfill areas of the northern shore.
This is the place that the British colonists invested. So, it seems like a good starting point, if you are looking for evidence of colonial history in this region.
The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove belt in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the backwaters of Bangladesh and India.
UNESCO declared the Sundarbans a World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called the Sundarbans National Park.
However, forests are not composed solely of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last vestiges of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km², of which about a third is covered by water/marshy areas.
Sundarbans is a nature reserve since 1966, you can find about 400 Royal Bengal Tigers and 30,000 spotted deer there.

The buses depart from the intercity bus station (located on the other side) throughout the day, but most, particularly those that serve east and Jakar/Bumthang, depart between 6:30 and 7:30 in the morning.
Inter-district buses are often full, so it is recommended to buy a ticket a few days in advance.
Most districts are served by small Japanese fishing boats, which are comfortable and robust.
Collective taxis are a quick and comfortable way to get to places nearby, such as Paro (150 Nu) and Punakha (200 Nu).
The Oyapock Bridge is a suspension bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to connect the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers are 83 metres high; it is 378 metres long and has two lanes of 3.5 metres wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was opened to traffic in March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guarani were the most important indigenous group inhabiting what is now the east of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes who inhabited the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived mainly through fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, formerly known as the "Giant Province of the Indies," was born from the meeting between Spanish conquerors and indigenous populations.
The Spaniards inaugurated the period of colonisation, which lasted three centuries.
Since the foundation of Asunción in 1537, Paraguay has managed to preserve much of its indigenous character and identity.
Argentina is known for having one of the best teams and among the best polo players in the world.
The biggest tournament of the year takes place in December on the polo fields of Las Cañitas.
In addition, tournaments and smaller matches are sometimes held here at other times of the year.
For information on polo tournaments and where to buy tickets for polo matches, see the Argentine Polo Association.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands Pound (FKP) which is equivalent to a British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the islands located at Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a widely accepted currency in the islands, while at Stanley, credit cards and U.S. dollars are also often accepted.

In the surrounding islands, credit cards will probably not be accepted, even if it is possible that British and American currency will be accepted. Talk to the owners beforehand to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falkland Islands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.
Montevideo being located south of Ecuador, winter in the northern hemisphere corresponds to summer there and vice versa.
Montevideo is located in the subtropical zone and summer temperatures exceeding 30 °C are common.
Winter can be deceivingly cold: temperatures rarely fall below zero, but wind and humidity combine to give the impression that it is colder than the thermometer says.
There is no such thing as a "rainy season" and a "dry season" : rainfall is fairly constant throughout the year.
Although many of the park's animals are used to seeing humans, they are wild animals; please do not feed or disturb them.
According to the park authorities, you should be at least 100 metres away from bears and wolves and 25 metres away from all other wild animals.
As docile as they may appear, bison, elk, moose, bear and almost all large animals can attack.
Each year, dozens of visitors are injured because they did not keep enough distance. These animals are large, wild and potentially dangerous, so give them space.
Also, know that odors attract bears and other wild animals, so avoid carrying or cooking smelly foods and keep the camp clean.
Apia is the capital of Samoa. The city is located on the island of Upolu and has about 40,000 inhabitants.
Apia was founded in the 1850s and is the official capital of Samoa since 1959.
The port was the site of a notoriously infamous naval impasse in 1889, when seven ships from Germany, the United States and Britain refused to leave the port.
All ships were sunk, with the exception of a British cruiser. Nearly 200 Americans and Germans lost their lives.
The supreme leader Tupua Tamasese Lealofi III was assassinated during a peaceful rally in the city, during the struggle for independence organized by the Mau movement.
The beaches are numerous, because Auckland is on two harbours. The most popular are in three areas.
The North Shore beaches (in the North Harbour district) are on the Pacific Ocean and stretch from Long Bay to the north to Devonport to the south.
Most beaches are sandy and allow safe swimming, and most are shaded by pohutukawa.
The Tamaki Drive beaches are on the Waitemata Harbour, in the chic suburbs of Mission Bay and Saint Heliers in the centre of Auckland.
These beaches, sometimes very popular with families, have many shops along the coast. Swimming is safe.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang from each side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the saddle, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First, most riders wear riding boots with a pointed heel and a smooth and narrow sole.
